definitions.definition: an act of holding somebody/something tightly; a particular way of doing this

examples.text: Keep a tight grip on the rope.
to **loosen/release/relax your grip**
She tried to **get a grip on** the icy rock.
The climber slipped and **lost her grip**.
She struggled from his grip.
Try adjusting your grip on the racket.
He finally broke her grip and escaped.
He still had a firm grip on my arm.
Her upper arms were seized in an iron grip.
His grip slackened and she tore herself away.
Hold the microphone in a firm grip.
Keep a secure grip on the rope at all times.
Robert tightened his grip on the steering wheel.
She relaxed her grip on the door frame.
She slipped and lost her grip of the rope.
Taking a tight grip on the hook, he began to pull it closer.
Winter still held them in its iron grip.
The home team took a firm grip on the game.
We need to tighten the grip we have on the market.
The Prime Minister needs to keep a tight grip on his party.
We need to keep a tight grip on costs.
They managed to strengthen their grip on the southern part of the country.
The Church does not have a strong grip on the population.
I couldn't get a grip on what was going on.
You need to keep a good grip on reality in this job.
The government does not seem to have a very firm grip on the economy.
She has a tenuous grip on reality.

definitions.definition: the ability of something to move over a surface without slipping

examples.text: These tyres give the bus better grip in slippery conditions.
This type of sole gives a good grip on snow and ice.

definitions.definition: a part of something that has a special surface so that it can be held without the hands slipping

examples.text: the grip on a golf club

definitions.definition: a small thin piece of metal or plastic folded in the middle, used by women for holding their hair in place
a person who prepares and moves the cameras, and sometimes the lighting equipment, when a film is being made
a large soft bag, used when travelling
to begin to understand and deal with something difficult

examples.text: I'm slowly getting to grips with the language.
They have so far failed to come to grips with the ecological problems.

definitions.definition: to improve your behaviour or control your emotions after being afraid, upset or angry

examples.text: I have to take a grip on myself, he told himself firmly.
**Get a grip**! *(= make an effort to control your emotions)*

definitions.definition: experiencing something unpleasant that cannot be stopped

examples.text: a country in the grip of recession

definitions.definition: to become unable to understand or control a situation

examples.text: Sometimes I feel I'm losing my grip.

wordOrigin: Old English grippa (verb), gripe ‘grasp, clutch’ (noun), gripa ‘handful, sheath’; related to gripe.
